notesStmt.note: A leaf is missing after folio 8. Some signs of worming. Ink fading on several pages.

Note of former owners, folio 1r. The manuscript once belonged to the Norzi family. Domenico Irosolimitano, Italian censor (active 1575-1624): inscribed with his name, 1600 (folio 357v); see 61. Giovanni Domenico Carretto, Italian censor (active 1600-1624): inscribed with his name, 1618 (folio 356v); see 100-101.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: The commentary of Naḥmanides (Moshe ben Nahman aka ha-Ramban) on the Pentateuch, followed by his prayer and additional comments.

collation.p: 27 quires of mostly 10 leaves each. Catchwords at the end of the quires (sometimes cut away), with Hebrew letters as signatures written partly over and partly under the respective catchword. The Hebrew signatures are omitted in the latter portion of the manuscript.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Fine Italian semi-cursive script, unpunctuated, of the 15th century.

binding.p: BM/BL in-house. Spine: 'Moses ben Nahman. Commentary on the Pentateuch. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Harley Ms. 5,703.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
